awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Developing a multi-scale understanding of microtubule dynamic instability
awd_abstract_narration:
Most cells in a wide range of organisms contain a dynamic substructure called the cytoskeleton, a network of protein-based polymers and associated proteins that has fundamental roles in cell movement, DNA partitioning, and internal cell organization. A key aspect of many cytoskeletal polymers is that they require chemical energy in the form of ATP (or GTP) to maintain a polymerized state. The harnessing of this energy allows the cytoskeletal filaments to do work, respond dynamically to internal and external signals, and self-organize. The major goal of the work in this project is to use a combination of experiments and computational modeling to develop an improved theoretical framework for understanding and predicting the behaviors of these dynamic cytoskeletal polymers as observed at different scales. More specifically, the proposed work sets out to establish how the biochemical properties of the polymer subunits (including the rate at which they burn ATP or GTP) relate to the behaviors of the individual filaments and to the overall behaviors of populations of filaments. In addition, the project studies how filament binding proteins work together to regulate filament dynamics. While this work is basic science, it has the potential to have practical applications in nanotechnology and synthetic biology. Through this project, graduate students and undergraduates will receive interdisciplinary training in both computational modeling and experimental biology. High school teachers and students will also be engaged in the research process. Freely available, open-source software and tutorials produced through this project will help students and researchers at all levels gain an intuitive understanding of dynamic polymer systems.

From a technical perspective, the project has four specific goals, most of which focus on a type of cytoskeletal filaments known as microtubules. Individual microtubules exhibit a dramatic behavior known as dynamic instability, in which they stochastically alternate between extended periods of growth and depolymerization. (1) The first project goal is to develop and test hypotheses for the mechanisms of the transitions in microtubule dynamic instability by relating the behaviors of the filaments to the subunit-level structure of their tips. The approach will utilize a combination of work with a previously established detailed computational model of microtubule dynamics, a novel data analysis tool for identifying and statistically categorizing the microtubule behaviors, and experimental data acquired at high temporal and spatial resolutions. (2) The second goal is to establish a predictive understanding of the relationships between the biochemical characteristics of the subunits (kinetic rate constants), the behaviors of the filaments (e.g., dynamic instability, treadmilling) and the attributes of the polymer systems (e.g., critical concentrations, steady states). The approach will utilize a combination of computational modeling (performed with variants of the model used in Goal 1) and experiments with a bacterial relative of tubulin called PhuZ (chosen because wildtype and altered versions of this protein can be expressed in bacteria and characterized in vitro). (3) The third goal is to use a combination of experiments and computational models to test a set of hypotheses for how a group of filament binding proteins known as +TIPs (microtubule plus-end tracking proteins) work together to regulate microtubule behavior. (4) The final goal is to create for broad distribution packages of our software and associated analysis tools used in Goals 1 to 3. These packages will include software targeted at both the research and teaching communities. While the focus of our studies is on microtubules, the resulting multi-scale understanding of polymerizing filament systems should apply to steady-state (energy-utilizing) polymers more generally, including actin, bacterial filaments, and polymers created through biotechnology.

por.por_cntn:
How do cells divide, organize themselves internally, and move?  These fundamental life processes involve the cytoskeleton, a dynamic network of protein-based polymers, motors and regulators that create force and drive movement. A key aspect of many cytoskeletal polymers is that they require chemical energy in the form of ATP (or GTP) to maintain a polymerized state. The harnessing of this energy allows the cytoskeletal filaments to do work, respond dynamically to internal and external signals, and self-organize. 

The major goal of the work in this project was to use a combination of experiments and computer models to begin to identify the general principles that govern the behaviors of these dynamic, energy-using polymers as they are observed at different scales (subunits, filaments, and populations of filaments). We were particularly interested to understand how the behaviors of polymers that require energy to assemble differ from those that do not. Another long-term goal was to identify what causes the filaments to suddenly undergo changes in behavior, e.g., from growth to shrinking or vice versa.

Most of our work focused on a type of cytoskeletal filaments called microtubules, which display a striking behavior called dynamic instability where filaments undergo periods of growth and depolymerization with approximately random transitions in between, termed “catastrophe” and “rescue.” However, many of our findings should apply to energy-utilizing polymers more broadly. Our project has relevance to both agriculture and health because many herbicides, fungicides and anti-cancer agents target microtubules. Moreover, the improved predictive understanding of energy-utilizing polymers developed through this work has potential applications in nanotechnology and bioengineering. 

Key accomplishments of this project include the following:

1)    To explain the various behaviors displayed by microtubules and similar polymers requires first quantifying and classifying these behaviors. However, existing methods for doing so were subjective and ignored types of length change intermediate between simple growth and shrinking. The existence of such intermediate behaviors has recently become obvious from data acquired at higher temporal resolution and is interesting because it seems likely to be relevant to the mechanism of transitions between growth and shrinking. To address this problem, we developed a machine-learning-based tool called STADIA (Statistical Tool for Automated Dynamic Instability Analysis) to objectively classify and quantify microtubule behavior. STADIA is built on the familiar MATLAB platform, and it is open-source and freely-available.

2)    We used STADIA to quantify microtubule behavior in our detailed computer simulation of microtubule dynamics (this was useful for initial development and tuning of our software) and in vitro (i.e., in a test tube, with purified proteins). Using STADIA, we showed the following:

a.     Microtubules both in vitro and in computer models frequently display brief periods (~0.5-3 seconds) of reduced change during both growth and shortening. We termed these events “stutters.”

b.     Transitions from growth to shortening (termed catastrophe) are typically “transitional,” i.e., they are usually preceded by stutters, providing insight into the mechanism of microtubule catastrophes.  

c.     We demonstrated that STADIA is useful for studying microtubule binding proteins by determining how a core component of the cytoskeleton called “CLASP” affects microtubule dynamics. We showed that CLASP works by converting transitional catastrophes (where the behavior sequence is growth-stutter-depolymerization) into interrupted growth (i.e., growth-stutter-growth).

1)    The third major accomplishment of our project was that we used our computer simulations to study and improve understanding of microtubule behaviors across size scales.  More specifically, for the first time, we provided a clear and intuitive demonstration of how the behaviors of the individual filaments relate to behaviors observed at the level of the bulk polymer. This work enabled us to identify what we believe are some general principles of energy-utilizing polymers; having these principles in-hand lays the groundwork for creating a unified predictive understanding of these filament systems. The fact that we used computer simulations for this work was important because experiments with physical systems typically limit scientists to examining only one scale at a time, leading to gaps in understanding. 

Overall, the work completed in this project resulted in ten publications and should help improve design and interpretation of experiments involving cytoskeletal proteins, leading to improved reproducibility in experiments. The improved understanding of microtubules developed from our work should also promote efforts to develop improved drugs for agriculture and health and help with design of artificial energy-utilizing polymers for nanotechnology and bioengineering.

With regard to Broader Impacts, one major accomplishment was that this project provided hands-on training of post-docs (2), PhD students (6), undergraduates (5), high school students (4), and high school teachers (3) in interdisciplinary research at the interface between cell biology, biophysics, and applied math. Each of the four years, Dr. Goodson served as a Science Olympiad coach at Adams HS, a local public school with significant populations of minority and economically disadvantaged students. Finally, Dr. Goodson continued to serve as a co-organizer of regional Chicago Cytoskeleton conferences.
